conclusion: To solve the problem, the flow paths of liquid through the baffles will be analyzed to determine which container (D or E) the liquid will flow into.
The image depicts a fluid flow system with liquid exiting from points labeled A, B, and C, flowing through rectangular baffles, and reaching containers D and E positioned at the bottom.
The problem requires identifying which container (D or E) the liquid will flow into after passing through the baffles.
The image shows three initial liquid sources at points A, B, and C, with liquids flowing through baffles and into containers.
The pathways created by the baffles must be observed to understand the flow of liquids from A, B, and C.
The connections between the channels from A, B, and C to containers D and E must be analyzed to identify shared or exclusive pathways.
Path intersections or merges must be determined to establish which liquid ends up in each container.
Based on pathway connections, each liquid source is assigned to the container where it ultimately ends up.
The liquid originating from A will flow into container D.
The liquid originating from B will flow into container E.
The liquid originating from C will flow into container D.
Since the flow from A goes to D and the flow from B goes to E, the answer is D.
